name: chicagotribune
text:
Chicago’s Dreadhead Cowboy roams the streets on horseback, rallying protesters and offering rides to starry-eyed kids.

“That’s our Batman.” https://t.co/KQJuZUOXb0

name: chicagotribune
text: Column from @PWSullivan: Taking it one day at a time isn’t just a baseball cliche in 2020. It’s the only way we’ll make it through this mini-season. https://t.co/x8ni2xBDY4

name: chicagotribune
text: COVID-19 cases in Illinois by ZIP code: Search for your neighborhood. https://t.co/vmTv0wnphM

name: chicagotribune
text: You think the first half of 2020 was unpredictable? Wait until the second half. Here's what's on the horizon in the year ahead. https://t.co/agYjsSbjuh

name: chicagotribune
text: Photos: Family and friends gather Sunday for a vigil for 7-year-old Natalia Wallace, who was killed Saturday as her family celebrated the Fourth of July in the South Austin neighborhood of Chicago. https://t.co/J9EAl50pFb

name: chicagotribune
text: The coronavirus pandemic hasn't affected all parts of Chicago in the same way. Some areas have been hit much harder than others, and now scientists are setting out to discover why. https://t.co/qFZfTafriJ

name: chicagotribune
text: Broadway actor Nick Cordero has died at age 41, after months hospitalized for coronavirus complications. Cordero was known for his roles in “Rock of Ages,” “Waitress” and “A Bronx Tale The Musical.” https://t.co/xOlQNhoVQo

name: chicagotribune
text: 4 takeaways from Chicago Cubs camp Sunday, including the starting pitchers’ varying stages of readiness and the removal (finally) of a profane comment about LeBron James https://t.co/QFo8WgQibJ

name: chicagotribune
text: A Glock 19 decorated with President Donald Trump's image was among weapons confiscated by Chicago police this weekend. https://t.co/v3UNO2nVOI

name: chicagotribune
text: Commentary: The questions we should be asking about the Russian bounties on U.S. troops https://t.co/f5OHDs7O3A

name: chicagotribune
text: Photos: FroSkate hosts a gathering of skateboarders, roller skaters, in-line skaters and cyclists in Grant Park on July 4 to call for Black power, the defense of Black lives, the divestment of the police and investment in their communities. https://t.co/XURuY0TD5B

name: chicagotribune
text: This weekend, Chicago continued to struggle with a harsh wave of violence that has taken the lives of young children in the last few weeks https://t.co/1RQT98FhMU

name: chicagotribune
text:
Racial disparities in who contracts the virus have played out in big cities like Milwaukee and New York, but also in smaller metropolitan areas like Grand Rapids, Michigan.

Story from The New York Times: https://t.co/mJFRNb5rBH

name: chicagotribune
text:
A community group in Back of the Yards has raised thousands of dollars to support Chicago street vendors who missed out on federal coronavirus aid.

“I’m so grateful because even though it is not a lot, it meant a lot to feel the support from them.” https://t.co/iVxExhXVA1

name: chicagotribune
text: A new crisis looms for America's children: distance education, writes Amy Hinojosa. https://t.co/v8JMo0w3UH

name: chicagotribune
text: Is it worth the risk to go back to the office, restaurants or the gym? Should I keep my mask on at all times at the zoo or museums? Experts weigh in on those questions and more. https://t.co/gS3vq1VL0O

name: chicagotribune
text: Oscar-winning Italian composer Ennio Morricone, who created the coyote-howl theme for the Spaghetti Western “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly,” among other films, died on Monday. He was 91. https://t.co/yrXyQPdtlD

name: chicagotribune
text: This weekend marked the third consecutive week that young children have been killed in gun violence in Chicago. https://t.co/9rBEQuyfUo

name: chicagotribune
text: One person was in custody and charges were pending Monday in the killing of a 7-year-old girl shot as she visited her grandmother, Chicago police said. https://t.co/v4GqQ7xoGh

name: chicagotribune
text:
Good morning, Chicago. Here are some top stories to start your day:
–Violence claims lives of more Chicago children
–"Busiest courthouse in America" reopens today
–Workplace tensions over Black Lives Matter face masks
https://t.co/MVsGIFGQai

name: chicagotribune
text: Antonio McDowell walked out of a state prison last month a free man, his murder sentence commuted to time served amid the coronavirus pandemic. Now, he's eager to put his past behind him and committed to proving he was wrongfully convicted. https://t.co/xCOZhfIi0q

name: chicagotribune
text: Nearly 200 police departments have signed on to the Ten Shared Principles, an agreement between the Illinois NAACP State Conference and the Illinois Association of Chiefs of Police on ways to improve policing. But some activists say it falls short. https://t.co/43COQ0NXtx

name: chicagotribune
text: Employees have staged protests at Whole Foods, denounced Trader Joe’s on Twitter, and called for boycotts of Taco Bell and Starbucks for not allowing them to wear masks or other attire that express solidarity with Black Lives Matter. https://t.co/ecws7RkbWy

name: chicagotribune
text: Adam Hollingsworth, known to many as the Dreadhead Cowboy, is using his growing celebrity to promote horseback riding in largely Black neighborhoods of Chicago. “If a horse can change my life, I know for a fact that it can change other people’s lives.” https://t.co/YppFHgvC93

name: chicagotribune
text: Right now, more known COVID-19 cases than ever exist among athletes. Logistically and morally, it just doesn’t make sense to move ahead with sports, writes Shannon Ryan. https://t.co/30y7ee6nIk

name: chicagotribune
text: Disney has been banking on “Hamilton” to reel in paying customers. It remains a question, of course, how many new customers will stick around after the hype wears off. https://t.co/qwPeGAtRts

name: chicagotribune
text: Scores of stars paid tribute to Tony-nominated actor Nick Cordero on Sunday night following confirmation by his family that he had died from complications due to coronavirus. https://t.co/uJwT1KyNhE

text: The coronavirus is accelerating a shift toward a cashless future, raising new calculations for merchants and enriching the digital payments industry. https://t.co/9cNDGCvgJv

text: Uber will buy Postmates in a $2.65 billion all-stock deal, giving the company a larger share of the U.S. food delivery market https://t.co/J4p1IeOH8c

name: chicagotribune
text: Statues of Confederate generals and soldiers are being taken down across the country. But this auto museum has no plan to stop displaying a Dodge Charger with the Confederate battle flag painted atop the vehicle. https://t.co/y2H01iDI2m

name: chicagotribune
text: The Chicago Cubs will open their 60-game schedule on July 24 at Wrigley Field against the National League Central rival Milwaukee Brewers. https://t.co/6cJDNZo7HD

name: chicagotribune
text:
Experts say the coronavirus seems to be most infectious when people are in prolonged contact at close range, especially indoors, and even more so in superspreader events — exactly what scientists would expect from aerosol transmission.

Via New York Times: https://t.co/vKb3wEjPVJ

name: chicagotribune
text: 40 lobbyists with ties to President Donald Trump helped clients secure more than $10 billion in federal coronavirus aid, among them 5 former administration officials whose work potentially violates Trump's own ethics policy, according to a watchdog report. https://t.co/KF3PtRl0k2

name: chicagotribune
text: Summer is usually the busiest time of year for these rodeo horses. But for months, they haven’t done much besides graze on Calzavara’s pasture in Harvard, Illinois. https://t.co/LL6BV4Z0Ko

text: Country musician Charlie Daniels, known for his hit song “The Devil Went Down to Georgia,” has died. He was 83. https://t.co/VLzUe2sjNr
